projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Church of England -- Creeds -- Early works to 1800.

figure.p: ¶ A general Confeſſion ſet furth for all Men and ſaruauntes to ſay euery morning before they go to their worke or other buſines, alſo graces before dynner & Supper

div.p:
O Mercieful & moſt louing Father whoſe loue is infinit, whoſe merci indureth for euer, we ſinful creatures, truſting in thyne vnſpeakeable goodnes and loue towards vs, do appere this morning before thy deuyne maieſtye, moſt lowlye confeſſyng our manifold ſinnes, and innumerable tranſgreſſyons of thy commaundements, and fatherly wil. Againſt the onelye, agaynſte the (O Lorde: haue we ſynned, therfore we confeſſe oure ſynnes, we knowledg our offēces, we accuſe our ſelues vnto the O mercyfull lord, & wyl not hyde our vnryghtouſnes.
We finde in oure ſelues nothinge but ignorance of thy wil diſobedience, miſtruſte, doutefulnes in thy goodnes, and incredulitiy, hatred, and contēpt of al ſpirytuall thynges, ſelfeloue, confydence in oure ſelues and feruēt luſtyng after carnal thynges of thys worlde. And this tree of oure corrupt nature, bringeth forth contynually in vs none other frute, but rottē, and vnſauery workes of the fleſhe, in thoughtes wordes and doynges, vnto condempnacyon. Wherfore, we humbly beſeche thy fatherlye goodneſſe, euen for thy ſonne Ieſus Chriſtes ſake, whom thou haſt ſet forth for a purchaſer towarde vs of mercye, throughe faith in his bloude: to make oure hertes clene, take away our ſtonye hertes, & geue vnto vs a true and
a lyuely faith, whiche ſhall worcke contynuallye by loue, throughe Chriſt. Haue mercy vpon vs, forgeue vs our ſinnes, for thy ſonnes ſake, certifye our Conſcience of remiſſion of the ſame, by thy holye ſpirit, by whoſe operacion, ſo mortify in vs our old man, the whole body of ſinne, that we continualy, dying vnto ſin may walcke in newneſſe of lyfe, to the glorye of thy name, through Ieſus Chriſte our Lorde. So be it.

div.head: ☞ Then ſay thys. lxxxvi. Pſalme followyng treatably.
div.p: BOwe downe thyne eare (O Lorde) and heare me, for I am pore and in miſery.

O preſerue my ſoule, for I am holye: my God ſaue thy ſeruaunte, that putteth
hys truſt in the.
Be mercyful vnto me (O Lord) for I wyl cal dayly vpon the. Comforte the ſoule of thy ſeruant for vnto the (O Lorde) do I lyfte vp my ſoule.
For thou Lord arte good and gracious, and of great mercy vnto al them that cal vpon the.
Geue eare Lorde to my prayer, and ponder the voyce of my humble deſyres.
In the time of my trouble I wyl cal vpon the, for thou heareſt me. Amonge the Gods there is none lyke vnto the (O Lorde) there is not one that can do as thou doſte.
Al naciōs whō thou haſte made ſhall come and worſhyppe the, O Lord: and ſhal glorify thy name.

For thou art great, & doeſt wonderous thynges, yu arte God alone
Teache me thy way (O Lord) & I wil walke in thy truth: O knit my herte vnto the, that it maye feare thy name.
I wil thāke, ye O lord my God, with al my hart, & wyll prayſe thy name for euer.
For great is thy mercy towarde me, and thou haſte delyuered my ſoule from the nethermooſte helle.
O God, the proude are ryſen agaynſte me, and the congregacyons of naughty men haue ſought after my ſoule, and haue not ſet ye before theyr eyes.
But thou O lord God, art full of compaſſion, & mercy, longe ſuffering, plenteous in goodnes and truthe.

O turne the then vnto me, and haue mercye vpon me: geue thy
ſtrength vnto the ſeruaunt, and helpe the ſon of thyn handmaid. Shewe ſome token vpon me for good, yt they which hate me may ſe it, & be aſhamed, becauſe thou Lord haſt helped me, & cōmforted me.
Glori be to the father, to the ſōne and the holy ghoſt.
As it was in the begynnynge, is now, & euer ſhalbe world wythout ende. Amen.
☞ Lord haue mercie vpon vs.
Chriſt haue mercie vpon vs.
Lord haue mercy vpō vs.

div.head: Then ſaie the Crede & the lordes praier. &c.
div.p: Lord ſhew thy mercy vpon vs.
And graunte vs thi ſaluacion.
¶ O Lorde ſaue the King.
And mercifulli here vs whē we cal vppon the.
Indue thy mynyſters wt rightuouſnes.
div.l: And make thi choſen people Ioiful:
¶ Gyue peace in our tyme O Lord.
Becauſe there is none other yt fighteth for vs but onli thou O God:
✚ O God mak clene oure heartes within vs
And take not thy holy ſpirite from vs.

div.head: Let vs praie.
div.p: O God which art autor of peace & louer of concorde, in knoledge of whom ſtā deth oure eternall lyfe whoſe ſeruyce is perfect fredome: defēde vs thy humble ſeruantes in al aſſults of our enemyes, that we ſuerly truſting in thy defēce, may not feare the power of ani aduerſaries, tho rowe the myght of Ieſu Chriſte our Lord. Amen.

O Lord our heauēlye father almyghty & euerlaſtynge God, whyche haſt ſafely brought vs to the beginninge of this day: defēd vs in the ſame with thi mightye power, and graunt that thys daye we fall into no ſynne, nether runne into anye kynd of daūger, but that al our doings may be or dred by thy gouernaūce, to do all wayes that is ryghtuous in thy ſyght, through Ieſus Chriſt our Lord. Amen.

div.head: A prayer for the Kynges Maieſtye.
div.p:
ALmyghtye God whoſe kingdom is euerlaſting and power infinit, haue mercye vpon the whole congregacion, and ſo rule the hart of thy choſen ſeruaūt, Edward the ſyxte, oure kyng & gouernour that
he (knowyng whoſe miniſter he is may aboue al thynges, ſeke thy honoure and glorye: and that we hys ſubiectes (duely conſidering whoſe authoryty he hath) may faithfully ſerue, honoure, and humblye obeye hym, in the, and for the, accordyng to thy bleſſed worde & ordinaunce: Thorow Ieſus Chriſt our Lorde who wyth the, and the holye gooſt, lyueth and reigneth euer one god, worlde wythout ende. Amen.

div.head: ¶ Grace before Dynner.
div.p:
IEſus Chriſte the ſonne of God, that for our ſakes dyddeſt dye and ſhed thy moſte precious bloud, for the forgeuenes of our ſins, bleſſe thou theſe our meates and drinks, which we purpoſe at this time to receiue in thy name, & aſſyſt vs O Lord, wyth thy grace
of thy holy ſpirit, to amend our lyues, that according to thy holye & pure Goſpel, we may lyue to thy glorye, and the profyte of our brethren. And when the daies of this oure pylgrymage ſhal be ended, graunt vs to finiſh ye ſame in thy peace, that we may at the daye of iudgement, haue a ioyfull reſurreccion into euerlaſting lyfe: thorough thy moſt precious deathe: whiche art the ſonne of God and our euerlaſting ſauiour. To whō with the father, and the holy goſt be all honoure, glory, and prayſe for euer and euer. Amen.

GOd preſerue Kynge Edwarde the .vi. God deſtroye all hys ennemyes. God preſeruehys Syſters, wyth all hys moſte honourable Counſellers God ayd the clargy wyth hys ſpirit inſettyng furth of his truth. God preſerue al ye Nobiliti of this relme and all the Commones of the ſame. God defende the fauourers of the Goſpell. God chaunge the harts of
our ennemyes, and ſend them a better mynde. The power of God deſtroye Antichriſte, wyth al hys wycked kyngdome. God ſende the goſpel a ioyful & a fre paſſage throughout the whole world. God ſende vnto al degrees ſuche grace that they may walke worthely in their vocacion and callynge. Amen.

☞ The peace of God, whych paſſeth al vnderſtandyng, kepe our her tes and mindes in the knoweledge and loue of God, and of hys ſonne Ieſus Chriſt our Lord. And the bleſſynge of God almyghty, the father the ſonne, and the holye goſte be amongeſte vs, and remayne wyth vs alwaye. Amen.

div.head: ¶ Grace after Dynner.
div.p:
O Lord whych art the creator of all creatures, and haſte prepared for theym to do accordynge to the nature of theyr creacion: we moſte hartelye thanke the for theſe thy creatures whyche at thys tyme we receyued in thy name, beſechinge the (O father) that as our bodyes are nowe
by theſe thy gyftes refreſhed: ſo oure ſoule maye alſo be noury ſhed with the fode of euerlaſtynge life, in thy moſt holy teſtamēt, confirmed with the bloud and deathe of Ieſus Chriſte thy ſonne and our ſauioure. To whō wyth the eternall father, and the holye goſte, be al honoure, glorye, & prayſe for euer andeuer, Amen.
God preſerue Kynge Edward. &c.

div.head: Grace before Supper.
div.p:
BRrethren, in that we are nowe here gathered together in the name of the Lorde, to taſte of theſe his gifts, which he hath ſent vs, let vs fyrſt geue him moſt hartye thākes, for theſe & all other hys benefites, ſhewed vpō vs, callyng for grace of his holy ſpirit, that we maye daily growe into perfeccyon of godlines, to ye glory of his moſte bleſſed name, and the cōforte of all
our brethren, mindful of their neceſſitis, & to ſuccoure & helpe them being members of one body wyth vs, hauyng one head Ieſus chriſt which gaue him ſelfe for vs, a ſacrifice of ſwete ſauoure vnto God the father, for the remiſſion of oure ſinnes, through his moſt precious bloude for euer & euer. To whom wyth hym, and the holy goſt be al honoure, glory, and prayſe worlde without end. So be it, God pre. &c

div.head: Grace after Supper.
div.p:
VVe thancke the O heauenlye father, whyche of thy aboundaunte goodneſſe, haſte thys daye ſente vs our foode in due ſeaſon, to noryſh theſe our mortall bodies, with beſeching alſo of thy infinite mercye, to pardon and forgiue vs all our offences, whych we haue cōmitted againſte thy deuyne maieſty, that we maye thys nighte
reſte in the with a quiete conſciēce abiding thy holy hand in the morening, to aryſe vs vp to do ye thyng that ſhalbe pleaſaunt in thy ſyght to thy glory, and our ſoule healthe graunt this o father, for thy dearely beloued ſons ſake Ieſus Chriſte our euerlaſting ſauiour. To whō with the & the holye goſt, be al honour, glory and prayſe, for euer & euer. Amen. God preſerue. &c.
Imprinted at London by Iohn Daye, dwelling ouer Alderſgare beneth Saynte Martins.
